text.p: Following are some of the top headlines in leading Italian newspapers.
* Prime minister Romano Prodi, facing opposition from key hard-left allies over proposed income tax modifications, says the 1997 budget will not hit lower earners (all).
* Opposition leader Silvio Berlusconi, commenting over clashes within the ruling coalition over the 1997 budget, says "It looks like a comic story, but the future of the country is at stake" (all).

* Finance minister Vincenzo Visco denies the special tax for Europe will hit car, motorcycle and mobile phone owners as reported by newspapers. "The Eurotax will not hit consumer spending" (Repubblica, Corriere della Sera).
* Treasury minister Carlo Azeglio Ciampi says the 1997 budget should come out from Parliament "strengthened, not diluted" (La Stampa).
* Analysts say the price for the second tranche sale of Eni (7,425 lire per share), which was fixed by the Treasury on Saturday, "is higher than expected but there will be a rush" (Repubblica).
Reuters has not verified these stories and cannot vouch for their accuracy.
